newsitem.title: USA: GM posts profits in domestic, overseas units.
newsitem.headline: GM posts profits in domestic, overseas units.

text.p: General Motors Corp reported strong profits in both its North American Operations (NAO) and International Operations as part of a $1.3 billion third quarter profit from continuing operations announced Tuesday.

Combined net income of NAO and Delphi Automotive Systems, GM's parts businesses, was $515 million, making it the first third-quarter profit for NAO-Delphi since 1986. The 1996 results were helped by a one-time gain that boosted the company's overall results by $253 million after taxes.
A year ago, NAO and Delphi had a combined loss of $93 million, with GM posting a profit of $396.7 million.
International Operations had net income of $323 million, up from a profit of $111 million a year ago. Net profit margin for international was as 3.9 percent, up from 1.6 percent.

GM Europe reported third quarter net income of $75 million, compared to a loss of $98 million a year ago. Income from the rest of the international operations, including Latin America, Asia and the Pacific regions, was $248 million, up from a profit of $209 million.
GM Chairman John Smith attributed the higher international profits to increased volume and favorable currency rates.

GM's overall profits were helped by an effective income tax rate of 2.8 percent. GM said the low rate resulted from favorable resolution of items related to prior-year tax returns, overall foreign tax rates that were lower than the U.S. statutory rate, and reinstatement of research and experimentation credits for the last half of 1996.
Smith also said the strength of its North American operations were due to continuing cost-reduction efforts.
"The success of our products in the marketplace is a reflection of our intense focus on the customer," he said in a statement.
